intro: Echinospermum intermedium, commonly known as the Mexican sunflower, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that resemble daisies. The plant produces yellow-orange ray flowers surrounding a central disc of tubular flowers, which attract pollinators like bees and butterflies. Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are upright and branching. Echinospermum intermedium is often cultivated for its ornamental value and ability to thrive in sunny, well-drained soils.
